And the wiener is ... Joey Chestnut, again! Twelve-time champion downs 71 hot dogs to win in 2019 Nathan’s Hot Dog Eating Contest on Thursday, July 4th. Photographed by @daniellehyams for @nydailynews . To see more images, click on the link in the bio.
Thousands take to the streets as they walk in the NYC Pride March on Sunday, June 30, 2019.  Photographed by @luizcribeiro and @daniellehyams . To see more images, click on the link in the bio.

A protester wears a colorful costume during the Queer Liberation March and rally on Sunday, June 30, 2019, the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall rebellion. The organizers said they march "against the exploitation of our communities for profit." Photographed by @luizcribeiro for New York Daily News. To see more images, click on the link in the bio.

1969 Mets team members  Cleon Jones, left, Jerry Koosman, and Ron Swoboda at a ceremony honoring former NY Mets player Tom Seaver outside Citifield in Queens on Thursday. New York City and The @mets honored Seaver by changing the address of @citifield to 41 Seaver Way, as well as renaming the street between Northern Blvd and Roosevelt Ave to 'Seaver Way.' For more info, click on the link in the bio. Photographed by Barry Williams for @nydailynews

Adolfo Voorduin of Mexico City held up a pride flag while standing on New York’s largest LBGTQ flag on the steps inside FDR Four Freedoms State Park, on Roosevelt Island during World Pride month. Photographed by @gjvigliotti for New York Daily News

100 YEARS BOLD!  The New York Daily News started publishing the print edition on June 26, 1919. To celebrate a century of the long-standing newspaper, click on the link in the bio, to see the pages of the first issue of Illustrated Daily News.
New Yorkers gather to watch the 62nd National Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday, June 9. Photographed by @luizcribeiro for New York Daily News. To see more images, click on the link in the bio.

Lightning flashes over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Tuesday night. Forecasters warned of an isolated tornado touching down in the five boroughs or its suburbs Wednesday as the strange and dangerous local weather stretched into a second day. Photographed by @mhermannphoto for New York Daily News.

Riverside Park celebrates the arrival of 24 goats on Tuesday, May 21, 2019. The herd of retired goats will spend the next few months feasting on invasive weed species as part of the Riverside Park Conservancy "Goatham" initiative. Photographed by @go.nakamura . To see more images, click on the link in the bio.
Pedestrians are seen next to the East River Esplanade with the view of the fog in the background on Sunday morning. Photographed by @theodoreparisienne for New York Daily News
The “super snow moon" rises over the Brooklyn on Tuesday, Feb. 19. Photographed by @luizcribeiro. To see more images, click on the link in the bio.
New Yorkers celebrate the year of the pig at the Lunar New Year Parade and Festival in Chinatown on Sunday. Photographed by @luizcribeiro . To see more images, click on the link in the bio.
The Statue of Liberty is seen during earlier today from the Jersey City side. Photographed by @luizcribeiro
The cold sunrise early Thursday morning behind One World Trade Center in New York City. Photographed by @luizcribeiro

New Yorkers were marching in the streets near Columbus Circle for the third annual Women's March on Saturday, January 19. Two Women's March took place in New York, One march through midtown Manhattan that was organized by the Women's March Alliance and the second march, a downtown Manhattan rally held at roughly the same time Women's March Inc., the group formed to help organize the 2017 demonstration in Washington, D.C. Photographed by @danimacphoto

Firefighters salutes the departing casket of Steven Pollard as FDNY holds a funeral procession for the fallen firefighter at Good Shepherd Church in Brooklyn on Friday, January 11. Photographed by @byronsmithphoto .  For more info/Images, click on the link in the bio.

Aiya Tulemaganbetova, left, presents Richard Taverna with an Altyn Adam sculpture, the golden warrior statute is a Kazakh icon of Independence, Prosperity and Heritage, when they met at the 20th Precinct on Thursday. Taverna found Tulemaganbetova's Chanel handbag on a bench with $10,000 in on the northbound 1 Train platform at 66th St. station on a bench on Dec. 20 and turned it in to the 20th Precinct on Dec. 21. Photographed by @barrywilliamsnyc .
The Steeplechase roller coaster at Coney Island this past weekend. Photographed by @shawninglima

Pedestrians walk past the art installation called "Wake" by artist Mel Chin, which is located in the middle of Manhattan's Times Square. "Wake," a sculpture that looks like the hull of a shipwreck will be placed next to the skeletal "remains" of a marine mammal. It will be active from July 11 to September 5 at the Broadway Plaza between 46th Street and 47th Street as part of Mel Chin: All Over the Place. Photographed by staffer @anthony.delmundo.photography

Widow Patricia Ann McDonald thanked the Mounted Unit officers at the plaque unveiling ceremony honoring her late husband Detective Steven McDonald in Central Park at 108th St, the location where he was shot in 1986. The ceremony was attended by McDonald's son NYPD Sergeant Conor McDonald, Mayor Bill de Blasio, Police Commissioner James O'Neill and former NYC Mayor David Dinkins on Thursday. “It’s a site where something horrible happened and that could have been the end of the story, but it was the beginning of a story that was so extraordinary and so inspiring,” Mayor de Blasio said his remarks honoring the late detective. Photographed by staffer @susanwatts3

Fans line up to watch NY Mets Noah Syndergaard warm up before pitching for the Brooklyn Cyclones at the MCU Park, Coney Island on Sunday. He made his first rehab start since landing on the disabled list in late May with a strained ligament in his right index finger. Photographed by staffer Andrew Savulich. “The first inning was a little rough,” Syndergaard said. “But I felt like I got in a good rhythm and a good groove as the game went on.”

Genesis Villella, center, and her twin siblings Peter, left, and Delilah Vega, the children of slain New York Police Department Detective Miosotis Familia during a street renaming ceremony outside the NYPD's 46th Precinct on Thursday, in the Bronx, N.Y.  The NYPD marked the one-year anniversary of Detective Familia's death with a memorial and street renaming outside the Bronx precinct where she worked. As Villella spoke, she recalled her mother as a hero and “the embodiment of strength” who loved her family and her city. Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . For more images, check out our Instagram stories.

Joey Chestnut, center, competes in the men's division of the 2018 Nathan's Famous Fourth Of July International Hot Dog Eating Contest on Wednesday, July 4. The king of competitive eating slammed down a record 74 franks in steamy Coney Island to easily capture his 11th Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog contest in the last 12 years. Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . To see more images, check out Instagram stories.

Yeni Gonzalez, right is hugged by volunteer Janey Pearl Starks outside the Cayuga Center on Park Avenue in Manhattan on Tuesday, July 3. Gonzalez was reunited with her three children after being detained and separated from them at the U.S. border in May. “Thank God I found them in good conditions. They were happy to see me. When they saw me they hugged me and they cried. They told me they want me to take them home soon,” the immigrant mom said after the private meeting. Photographed by staffer @marcussantos1
New Yorkers cooled off in the Washington Square Park fountain as temperatures scorched the city on Sunday.  Photographed by @luizcribeiro

Mourners packed into Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in the Bronx, on Wednesday to pay their last respects to Lesandro (Junior) Guzman-Feliz,  the 15-year-old who was murdered last week at the hands of a machete-wielding street gang. Pallbearers, included the victim’s father, Lisandro Guzman, wore Yankees jerseys as they honored the innocent teen who had dreamed of someday becoming a police officer. Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom

People gather at a memorial for stabbing victim Lesandro Guzman-Feliz, 15, at Cruz and Chiky Grocery store in the Bronx on Monday.  Police hauled five suspects into custody for the brutal mistaken-identity killing of the Bronx teenager in front of the grocery store.  Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . For more of the coverage, check out our instagram stories.

City Council Corey Johnson, along with many others walked in the 49th annual NYC Pride March that was held in the streets of Manhattan on Sunday. Photographed by @samfuller.nef , @jameskeivom and @luizcribeiro. To see more images from today’s march, check out our Instagram stories.

Sing for Hope, a non-profit organization that has been placing pianos in various places in New York City including "Broadway Melody", that was located in Times Square. This piano was designed by Playbill staffers to “celebrate the joy of the Broadway community with the Playbill’s past and present.” The 2018 Sing for Hope pianos will be on display until June 24. To see more images, check out our Instagram stories. Photographed by @samfuller.nef

Yogis participated in the Solstice in Times Square: Mind Over Madness Yoga, an annual all-day outdoor yoga event. It gave registered yogis the opportunity to join a free yoga session scheduled throughout the day. Photographed by @samfuller.nef, To see more images, check out our Instagram stories.

Celebrity chef and television personality Anthony Bourdain committed suicide in France early Friday. He was 61. "He was an exceptional human being, so inspiring and generous," said Eric Ripert, a longtime friend of Bourdain. "One of the great storytellers of our time who connected with so many. I wish him peace.” Bourdain, a New York City native who was raised in New Jersey, hosted a series of popular television shows on networks like Travel Channel and CNN. Bourdain is seen here at Siberia Bar in 2006, photographed by staffer @jameskeivom. For more photos celebrating the life of Anthony Bourdain, see our Instagram Stories.
The Statue of Liberty 🗽captured earlier this week by staffer @el_fab.
Members of the @nypd and @fdny played their annual charity Fun City Bowl football game at MCU Park in Coney Island on Saturday. The NYPD won. Photographed by @jeffb110
The 2018 Governors Ball Music Festival is taking place this weekend on Randalls Island. To see more, check out our Instagram stories! Photographed by staffer @twlevinson.
Fire boat Three Forty Three of Marine Company 1 sends up colorful sprays as it sails past the Brooklyn Bridge during the Blessing of Marine Fleets today, as photographed by Jefferson Siegel.

Disgraced Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein arrived at Manhattan criminal court on Friday to face rape and sex assault charges in connection with attacks on two women. Photographed by staffer @anthony.delmundo.photography.  For more info, click on the link in the bio.
Comedian Tracy Morgan drives a Lamborghini Convertible along 6th Avenue and West 48th Street in Manhattan on Thursday. Photographed by staffer @anthony.delmundo.photography
Oracle Challenger III plane flies over the Fleet Week procession of ships into New York Harbor on Wednesday.  Photographed by staffer @marcussantos1

The USS Arlington was given an 11-gun salute by the Fort Hamilton Army Base as it sails into New York Harbor passing under the Verrazano Bridge on Wednesday in Brooklyn. Photographed by staffer Todd Maisel. The Parade of Ships kicked off the 2018 Fleet week in New York.

What a ham! A lovable potbellied pig found wandering through the Bronx is headed for his new home upstate. Two-year-old Kalamazoo will be spending the rest of his days at a farm sanctuary in Middletown after departing the Animal Care Centers of NYC in Harlem today, as photographed by @susanwatts3. For more on Kalamazoo, see the link in our bio.

Ocean Wonders: Sharks! is the newest edition to the New York Aquarium in Coney Island. The exhibit features more than 115 marine species, including 18 species of sharks and rays. Spectators will have the opportunity to interact with divers as they swim inside the sprawling tanks. The grand opening will be on June 30th. Photographed by staffer @debbieeganchin . To see more images, click on the link in the bio.
Revelers take part in the Holi Hai color festival on Governors Island today, as photographed by @shawninglima.
Falun Dafa practitioners march along West 42th Street and 8th Avenue in Manhattan, New York to celebrate World Falun Dafa Day.  Photographed by staffer @anthony.delmundo.photography
Creatures of all kinds enjoy Union Square park in Manhattan today, as photographed by @susanwatts3.

Rihanna, Cardi B, Ariana Grande, Kim Kardashian-West were just a few that attended the Met Gala 2018 on Monday night. The Costume Institute Benefit celebrated the exhibition “Heavenly Bodies: Fashion and the Catholic Imagination.” Photographed by @wawawomp. For more on the Met Gala, click on the link in the bio.
Artist Sonny Sundancer seen working on a new mural on 8th street off of Sixth Avenue on Thursday. Photographed by staffer Howard Simmons.

Dozens of people, including activist Ravi Ragbir, march during the pro-immigrant "Jericho Walk" - a rally against strict immigration laws - outside the Federal Building in Lower Manhattan on Thursday. The Jericho Walk is "a prayerful vigil to ask for help," Ragbir said. Photographed by staffer Jefferson Siegel. For more info. click on the link in the bio.

New York gubernatorial candidate Cynthia Nixon attended a tenant rally in the Bronx on Thursday to propose a tenant-protection plan that includes dumping a provision that allows landlords to hike rents by 20% each time a rent-regulated apartment is vacated. "I will make protecting tenants — and not corporate landlords — my priority," Nixon said. Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . For more info, click on the link in the bio.
Artist Anselm Kiefer unveiled his newest art installation "Uraeus" located at Rockefeller Center on Tuesday morning.  Uraeus will be on display until July 22. Photographed by staffer Andrew Savulich.

@karengillanofficial wrote, directed and stars in @thepartysjustbeinningmovie - a film about a young Scottish woman dealing with the aftermath of the suicide of her transgender best friend, debuting at the Tribeca Film Festival. Gillan, who also stars in the new movie "Avengers: Infinity War," began this film with a statistic: every 10 days, a resident in her hometown of Inverness, Scotland, commits suicide. "I hope that people connect with it in their own personal way," says Gillan. "The most important thing isn't what I intended, but more what exists between each audience member and the film. It's different for each person." Photographed by @dereklreed on location at @tribecajournal. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Comedian Rob Schneider, the star of Netflix's "Real Rob," photographed by staffer @wawawomp . Schneider, who was part of the show's now-legendary cast that included Dana Carvey, Mike Myers, Chris Farley, Chris Rock, David Spade and Adam Sandler, says the show today is no different in some ways — yet when it comes to politics, they are too obviously "showing their hand" by consistently bashing President Trump and Republicans. "The fun of 'Saturday Night Live' was always you never knew which way they leaned politically," he told the Daily News. "You kind of assumed they would lean more left and liberal, but now the cat's out of the bag they are completely against Trump, which I think makes it less interesting because you know the direction the piece is going." For more info, click on the link in the bio.

For 47 years, 88-year-old Marie Gambardella manned the receptionist desk at the 76th Precinct in Carroll Gardens. On Wednesday, the beloved Gambardella was surrounded by hundreds of well-wishers who said goodbye to their longtime legend. Photographed by @susanwatts3. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer points to a wax figure of First Lady Melania Trump, left, and President Donald Trump during an unveiling at Madame Tussauds in Manhattan on Wednesday. Spicer was interviewed during the launch of the 'Give Melania a Voice' experience, featuring Madame Tussauds' first figure of First Lady Melania Trump. “If you get a chance to get up close, I’m not kidding, I looked at a photo I had with the First Lady before I left and I mean from a size, and uh, it’s pretty remarkable how lifelike it is,” Spicer said. Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

Evangelina Williams celebrated her 106th birthday on Friday with cheerful colored balloons, sweet layer cake — and, best of all, her beloved sister, Amparo Perez, who turns 104 in June. More than a century since sharing a bedroom as girls in Cuba, the women are happy being roommates at the Triboro Center for rehabilitation and nursing in the Concourse section of the Bronx. Photographed by staffer Howard Simmons. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

New York City students participate in the National School Walkout as part of a nationwide protest against gun violence, held at Washington Square Park in Manhattan on Friday morning.  The youth-led demonstrations that occurred in cities across the US were tied to the 19th anniversary of the massacre at Columbine High School in Colorado, where 15 people died. NYC Says Enough organizer Drew Myers said about 5,000 students from 40 public and private high schools participated in the protest that kicked off at noon. Photography by staffer @anthony.delmundo.photography.  For more info, click on the link in the bio.
Pedestrians walk by a colorful wall-covered mural at the corner of Broome Street and Chrystie Street in Manhattan today. Photographed by staffer @anthony.delmundo.photography

This year's graduating class that consisted of 448 recruits officially joined the NYPD on Wednesday during a ceremony at Madison Square Garden, as photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . To see more images from the NYPD graduation, click on the link in the bio.

NYC Parks department employees remove the monument of Dr. James Marion Sims from Central Park on Tuesday. The Public Design Commission on Monday voted unanimously to relocate the statue to Brooklyn’s Green-Wood Cemetery because Sims — once hailed as the father of modern gynecology — had experimented on enslaved women. Photographed by staffer Marcus Santos. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

Stormy Daniels leaves Manhattan Federal Court on Monday after attending a hearing for President Donald Trump's attorney Michael Cohen, as photographed by Jefferson Siegel. Daniels was paid $130,000 in a 2016 hush agreement over her alleged affair with Trump. Cohen and Trump lost their battle to block investigators from looking at records seized during a federal raid of Cohen's office and home. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.
Firefighters spring into action during a four alarm fire in Bensonhurst yesterday, as photographed by Todd Maisel. The fire left five people, including four firefighters, injured, but none seriously.

Goldie Sohn sings a rendition of "Ain't She Sweet" with friends while celebrating her 106th birthday in Brooklyn today, as photographed by @debbieeganchin. Sohn, who's the oldest member of the New York Road Runners, says her secret to longevity is exercising and friends, “Don’t sit still,” she said “You have to be happy.” For more on the celebration, see the link in our bio.

Members of the Legal Aid Society and Bronx Defenders protest the wrongful arrest of Rayon Smith outside the Bronx Hall of Justice on Monday, as captured by @jameskeivom. Smith was arrested by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents outside the court after an assault charge against him was dismissed, believing Smith was in the country illegally. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Holocaust survivors participate in a memorial candle lighting ceremony during New York’s Annual Gathering of Remembrance at Temple Emanu-El on Sunday in Manhattan. The gathering is held annually on the Sunday closest to Yom HaShoah, Holocaust Remembrance Day, on April 11.  Holocaust survivors and their families were among more than 2,000 people who attended the candlelight service to remember victims of the atrocity.  Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . For more info, click on the link in the bio.

Fwet G pours out a bottle of vodka in memory of Saheed Vassell, an unarmed man who was shot dead by cops in Crown Heights on Wednesday, at the scene of the shooting, as photographed by @byronsmithphoto. The tragic showdown between Vassell and cops lasted 10 seconds, with four officers firing a combined 10 shots after responding to three 911 calls reporting a man on the street with a gun. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Get out the tanning oil and start pumping those fists – “Jersey Shore” is back. The hit MTV show comes back on April 5 with “Jersey Shore Family Vacation,” starring your favorite guidos and guidettes who get up to more of their classic antics on the shores of Miami – “We have reunited to save reality TV once again,” said @mikethesituation. Now older, and maybe a little wiser, the crew stopped by the @nydailynews studio last week to answer some tough questions about fame and the new season. Photographed by @wawawomp. For more on the much anticipated reunion, see the link in our bio.

Carmella, the widow of fallen FDNY Lt. Christopher Raguso, is consoled by her two daughters at funeral services on Long Island today, as captured by David Wexler. Raguso was killed along with six others, including FDNY fire marshal Christopher “Tripp” Zanetis, in a helicopter crash in Iraq earlier this month.

Family, friends and fellow firefighters packed St. Patrick's Cathedral to honor fallen FDNY Lt. Michael Davidson, 37, who was killed while battling a five-alarm fire inside a Harlem apartment building. Davidson leaves behind his wife, Eileen, and their four young children. Photographed by @jameskeivom and Jefferson Siegel. For more photos, see the link in our bio.

Participants gather during the March for Our Lives rally on Saturday in Washington, D.C.  Student survivors of last month's mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School organized the march to honor the 17 students and faculty members who were killed on campus in Parkland, Fla. and to demand stricter gun control laws from their representatives.  Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . To see more images from the March for our lives rallies across the country, click on the link in the bio.

Firetrucks raise an American flag to honor fallen FDNY firefighter Michael Davidson in Floral Park on Friday, as photographed by @gonakamu. Davidson, 37, a veteran firefighter and father of four children, was killed battling a five alarm blaze in Harlem on Thursday night. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Eighth-grader Lena Santana, center, on stage with other Brooklyn Ascend charter school students, recites a poem during a rally against gun violence on the eve of the March for Our Lives rallies at Borough Hall on Friday.  Photographed by @byronsmithphoto. For more info, click on the link in the bio.
Washington Square Park in Manhattan, photographed by staffer @susanwatts3, on Thursday where the  sunshine mixes with the remnants of this week's nor'easter's melting snow.

Cynthia Nixon photographed during a Democratic gubernatorial primary campaign kickoff event at the Bethesda Healing Center in Brooklyn on Tuesday. The “Sex & the City” star was held up on her way to her very first event in Brownsville due to subway delays — a problem she lay at the feet of Gov. Cuomo. “I got here just in the nick of time. I allowed an hour and a half for what should have been a 30 minute ride,” Nixon told the crowd. “Cuomo's MTA.” Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

Firefighters work on a five-alarm fire at a recycling facility on Jamaica Avenue in Queens on Friday afternoon. According to the FDNY, the blaze was accidental due to "improper disposal of a lithium battery." Photographed by Gardiner Anderson.

The annual St. Patrick's day parade took place on Saturday, the event brought a horde of green-clad revelers to the Fifth Ave. parade route, where more than 100 marching bands and an assortment of bagpipers provided a soundtrack for the revelry. Photographed by @shawninglima. For more images, click on the link in the bio.

Students from hundreds of schools across NYC walked out of class on Wednesday morning in honor of kids who were gunned down at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida on February 14th. The walkout lasted 17 minutes to pay homage to the 17 people who lost their lives at the Parkland school. Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . For more info, click on the link in the bio.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo examines a bathroom in an apartment in the NYCHA's Andrew Jackson Houses in the Bronx on Monday. NYCHA tenants have been complaining about multiple repair issues for years and have long been suffering with miserable conditions in a bureaucratic twilight zone. “It is just shocking that in New York State we would have people subjected to these conditions,” he said after leaving the Jackson Houses apartment. “This situation we have seen is as upsetting and disturbing as I’ve seen anywhere and I’ve been in public housing across this country.” Photographed by staffer by @jameskeivom. For more info, click on the bio.

The chartered Liberty helicopter that crashed into the East River was hoisted from the waters on Monday. Five passengers aboard the chopper were killed in the crash that the pilot said was caused by one of their bags hitting a critical piece of equipment. “I extend our condolences to the families of the five passengers who did not survive," NYPD Commissioner James O'Neill said, adding that the National Transportation Safety Board and Federal Aviation Administration had joined the investigation. Photographed by staffer @marcussantos1. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

Mayor Bill de Blasio and First Lady Chirlane McCray held a gun violence town hall with students at the Vanderbilt YMCA on March 8, as photographed by @jameskeivom. "I really respected what they said and I frequently asked them what they thought, what they wanted to see different," Mayor de Blasio said today during his weekly radio appearance, but the students told the Daily News differently. "He didn't really hear us out the way he should have," said Andrea Colon, 17. "He was sort of dismissive in a way." For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

In honor of #InternationalWomensDay2018, Old Navy adorned NYC statues of inspirational women - like activist and diplomat Eleanor Roosevelt and the Fearless Girl -  with capes and wreaths of flowers, as photographed by staffer @susanwatts3. For more photos of celebrations, marches and rallies supporting women around the world, see the link in our bio.
New Yorkers brave the cold and snow near the MetroTech in Brooklyn today, as photographed by Barry Williams. For more photos from the winter storm, see the link in our bio.

Demonstrators ruffled feathers at the Health Department’s headquarters Tuesday in a dramatic protest of an Orthodox Jewish ritual that involves slaughtering chickens in the street.  Some 30 protesters caused a ruckus in the lobby of the Health Department’s office in Long Island City, Queens — imploring the city to ban the ancient practice known as Kaporos, which takes place before the start of Yom Kippur in early October — involves swinging a chicken three times overhead while saying a prayer.  Photographed on assignment by @gonakamu. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

Mourners leave flowers and mementos for two children who were killed by a driver who ran a red light in Park Slope yesterday. The deaths of the 1-year-old boy and 4-year-old girl, who were out for an afternoon walk with their moms, compelled concerned parents to confront Mayor Bill de Blasio earlier today with calls for safer local streets. “Obviously we can change intersections, we can put up speed cameras — we can do a whole host of things,” the mayor said. Photographed by staffers Todd Maisel and Jefferson Siegel. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Mayor Bill de Blasio named current Houston Superintendent Richard Carranza as the new city schools chancellor. Carranza, 51, joined de Blasio for a press conference Monday announcing his appointment at the Blue Room at City Hall along with current city schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña and First Lady Chirlane McCray. Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . “I’m looking forward to getting to know the city and making the city mine,” Carranza said. “I'm going to be in New York City as long as you’ll have me.” For more info, click on the link in the bio.

A massive tree fell on Sylvan Ave. in the Bronx during Friday's nor'easter, as photographed by @gjvigliotti. Power loss lingers across the East Coast, and flood warnings remain in effect until early tomorrow morning. For more on the damage caused by the storm, see the link in our bio.

Actor Justin Long reads Dr. Seuss' "The Cat In The Hat" to students from P.S. 9 aboard the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum, as captured by @anthony.delmundo.photography. The students, part of the Garden of Dreams Foundation, listened to celebrity guests read Dr. Seuss books to celebrate the famed authors birthday and Read Across America Day.

Fetty Wap leaves Brooklyn Supreme Court as a fan looks on, as photographed by Barry Williams. Fetty Wap will pay a fine after pleading guilty to drunk drag racing last year. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

New Yorkers enjoy the Purim holiday in Crown Heights today, as photographed by Todd Maisel. Purim is a Jewish celebration to commemorate the saving of the Jewish people from Haman. Celebrations include dressing up in costumes, a feast, and giving gifts. For more photos, see the link in our bio.

A construction worker is pulled from the rubble by the FDNY after he was buried under a heap of rubble at demolition site in Brooklyn today, as photographed by Todd Maisel. For an hour, firefighters and medics talked to the 33-year-old trapped worker as they reinforced part of the crumbled basement to free him. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Today, February 26, marks the 25th anniversary of the 1993 World Trade Center bombing. “For many of us, it is hard to believe that a quarter century has passed since that snowy winter day,” said Alice Greenwald, 9/11 Memorial and Museum director. “The 1993 bombing was the first act of terrorism at this site. As we know all too well, it would not be the last.” Greenwald was one of attendees at the World Trade Center site to hear the single toll of a silver bell at 12:18 p.m., marking the moment on Feb. 26, 1993 when the basement bomb went off and shattered America’s terrorist innocence. Photographed by staffer @susanwatts3 . For more info, click on the link in the bio.

Hundreds of union workers gathered in lower Manhattan on Saturday to chant, cheer and wave signs in a show of unity ahead of a Supreme Court hearing that could have a profound effect on organized labor. The Supreme Court will consider Janus vs. AFSCME - a controversial legal challenge to a longstanding precedent that protects the ability of public employee unions to represent their members and even nonmembers, and to speak out on matters of public interest.  Mayor de Blasio joined the Saturday rally and declared New York “the biggest union town” in America. “ We are proud of that ... We want to be a place where everyone who works hard is treated with dignity and lives a decent life,” he said. Photographed on assignment by @kevincdowns. For more info, click on the link in the bio.
Tyler, The Creator and Vince Staples perform at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 23, as photographed by @twlevinson. For more highlights from the show, see the link in our bio.

@joshuarush, @yourfriendlilan,  @peytonelizabethlee, and @sofia_wylie, from the Disney TV show "Andi Mack," pose for a photo in the NYDN studio, as photographed by @wawawomp. The popular show, now in its second season, has featured story lines many networks wouldn’t touch, let alone on a kid’s show. “The work that I’m doing is really helping people. It’s reminding people that they matter,” Rush, 16, told the Daily News. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.
Skater maneuvers through the melted ice at the rink in Bryant Park while temperatures climbed into the 70's on the warm Wednesday. Photographed by staffer @susanwatts3

Actress Amy Poehler, left, Shanita Thomas, a restaurant worker and member leader at Restaurant Opportunities Centers United, and Gemma Rossi, a New York City restaurant worker for 15 years, acknowledge their work in the service industry during a "One Fair Wage" event at The Rockefeller Foundation on Tuesday in Manhattan.  Poehler participated in the "One Fair Wage" campaign event that aims to establish better pay for workers in the food service industry. “When I was a struggling actress I waited tables in New York,” Poehler said. “I worked for the most part with very reasonable restaurant owners. But I did, like every women in this room, deal with incredible amounts of harassment from customers and co-workers. It was a very routine way of life.” Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . For more info, click on the link in the bio.

City Councilman Ritchie Torres, right, and Ja Rule join tenants and activists as they rally against NYCHA neglect on the steps of City Hall. “The mayor, the governor, they should all be ashamed of themselves. These are Americans, New Yorkers living in Third World conditions, and it should not be this way,” Ja Rule said Tuesday at a rally outside City Hall.  Photographed by staffer Jefferson Siegel. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

@yankees Giancarlo Stanton catching fly balls during Yankee Spring training in Tampa, Florida on Monday.  Stanton and Aaron Judge were in the same hitting group and were taking batting practice together at Steinbrenner Field. Photographed by staffer Andrew Savulich. To see more of the NYDN sports coverage from NYY Spring training,  click on the link in the bio.

A postal truck rapidly accelerated at Sands St. & Pearl St. and traveled up an embankment and perched atop a retaining wall of the Brooklyn Bridge entrance ramp around 9:00 a.m. on Sunday. The driver was not injured, but Manhattan-bound traffic was closed while police and fire personnel and a wrecker worked to dislodge the truck . Photographed by @mhermannphoto

Tim Tebow, photographed by staffer Howard Simmons, at the NY Mets Spring training at Port St. Lucie. It is Tebow's first major league spring training. Mets GM Sandy Alderson said Sunday that Tim Tebow will play in the major leagues at some point. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

Dragons dance at the entrance of Resorts World Casino for the celebration of Chinese Lunar New Year on Friday. Photographed on assignment by David Wexler.  To see more images from the Year of the Dog celebrations in New York, click on the link in the bio.

Workers install the floor-to-ceiling "fish tornado" in preparation for the new Unseen Oceans exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History today, as photographed by @anthony.delmundo.photography. Unseen Oceans is made up of dozens of models showing the wide array of newly-discovered biofluorescent species. The exhibit will open March 12, and run through January 6, 2019.

A bichon frise named Flynn takes a bow for the best in show at the 142nd annual Westminster Kennel Club dog show on Tuesday night. Photographed on assignment by @gonakamu. For more images from the Westminster Kennel dog show, you can check out our Instagram stories or click on the link in the bio.

Dr. Thomas Romo holds up a mirror so Jared Galicia could see his new ear implant that was sculpted from one of his ribs, on Monday, as photographed by @marcussantos1. Galicia was born with Treacher Collins syndrome - a rare condition that affects development of bones and tissue in the head and face - and plans to have more surgeries that will help him hear, and to build out his cheekbones and chin. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

A model poses during the Jill Stuart show during New York Fashion Week: The Shows at The National Arts Club in Manhattan. Photographed by staffer @twlevinson . To see more images from NYFW, click on the link in the bio.

St. John's Sophomore Shamorie Ponds drives to the basket against Marquette Golden Eagles Markus Howard on Saturday at Carnesecca Arena in Queens.. Ponds, originally from Brooklyn, finished with 44 points as the Red Storm win over Marquette 86 - 72.  Photographed by staffer Howard Simmons. For more info, click on the link in the bio.
Hardy Brooklyn dances in Times Square after having his body painted during the first Polar Bear Paint today, as photographed by @shawninglima.

Eight women shared their stories of how they both overcame and still struggle with past experiences of sexual misconduct, assault and rape during a #MeToo NYFW show in Manhattan on Feb. 9, as photographed by @chasegaewski. Organized by designer Myriam Chalek, the models left members of the audience silent as they bravely told their harrowing stories. For more images, see the link in our bio.

Zucker's Bagels and Acme Smoked Fish Corp. teamed up to break a Guinness World Record for the largest bagel and lox sandwich in Brooklyn today, as photographed by @kevincdowns. The bagel, topped with cream cheese, salmon from Nova Scotia, red onions, tomatoes and capers, clocked in at 213.75 lbs and 13 inches tall - and can feed up to 400 people.

Two attackers repeatedly stomped on Tylesha Mohammed's pregnant body on Feb. 1 at the bottom of a stairwell in the Bronx, stealing her phone and leaving Mohammed with face fractures and bruises. Mohammed, photographed here on Feb. 7 by @jameskeivom, said the two assailants came after her over a feud between them and a mutual friend. “I just want to stay home and rest for my daughter," said Mohammed, who is due in April. "I want her to be OK.” For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Six tenants of a Chinatown apartment building who were suddenly evicted last month started a hunger strike to demand a firm time to return to their home today, as photographed by Jefferson Siegel. The strikers - five of them seniors - set up a makeshift camp outside of the Department of Housing Preservation & Development in Lower Manhattan, planning only to drink water, tea and their medications until the vacate order is lifted and necessary repairs are finished. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.
A model has her makeup done before the Colovos show for New York Fashion Week F/W 2018 at Spring Studios in Manhattan today, as photographed by @anthony.delmundo.photography

NYCHA chairwoman Shola Olatoye testified under oath before the City Council members Tuesday about the record number of heating outages during the recent frigid temperatures. “Even with significant preparation, NYCHA’s infrastructure and dedicated staff were no match for the historic weather in early January,” Olatoye said. Photographed by staffer Jefferson Siegel. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

Natasha Capers,  a coordinator for NYC Coalition for Educational Justice, photographed during a demonstration at New York City Hall on Tuesday. Demonstrators gathered at City Hall to call on Mayor de Blasio to take action in the case of Middle School 118 teacher Patricia Cummings, who is currently being investigated by city education department officials for stepping on black students during a lesson on U.S. slavery.  Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom . For more info, click on the link in the bio.

The rescue went purr-fectly. Firefighters on Sunday saved a small cat that had gotten stuck deep inside the engine of a parked car on the Upper West Side. Photographed by staffer Andrew Savulich. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

A beloved German shepherd named Buddy, who gnawed off his own foot after it got ensnared in a wire, is going home with his foster dad Adam Brickner today, as photographed by @susanwatts3. Buddy was rescued by NYC Animal Care Centers outside of one of their shelters in East New York in January. “Buddy touched every one of our hearts here,” said Tony Cardona, manager of the veterinary hospital. “Our staff was in love with him. We’re sad to see him go, but so happy he’s recovered. We just hope he finds a good home.” For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Traffic was backed up for miles on the Belt Parkway after a car burst into flames today, as photographed by Todd Maisel. The blaze began about 1:30 p.m. near the Rockaway Parkway exit in Canarsie, officials said, and no injuries were reported. For more photos, see the link in our bio.

Ravi Ragbir yells with fellow protesters to send a message of resistance in front of 26 Federal Plaza today, as photographed by @jameskeivom. Local politicians and advocates criticized the arrest of Ragbir, an immigration activist, by the NYPD and ICE in January, which sparked protests throughout the city. Ragbir was released this past Monday from a federal detention center following a federal judge's ruling that keeping him behind bars was "unnecessarily cruel." For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Elizabeth Cascio is sworn in as the FDNY's new Chief of Staff today, as photographed by Todd Maisel. Commissioner Daniel Nigro swore in Cascio along with new First Deputy Commissioner Laura Kavanagh, declaring "As long as they're in the building, all is right in the world." For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

It was a ruff day for the Ruff Ryder. Rapper DMX arrives at federal court for a hearing in his tax evasion case today, and was then taken into custody for leaving a court-ordered drug treatment program, as photographed by @alectabak. DMX will likely remain in custody until his sentencing in March. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

The NYPD arrested three protesters after they climbed into the globe near Columbus Circle to unfurl a banner bashing President Trump's anti-immigration policies today, as photographed by @anthony.delmundo.photography. The protesters, who's banner read "Love No Border Stop the Deportations," directed their anger towards the Trump International Hotel on the same street. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

A single engine Cessna 172 had to make an emergency landing on Fire Island's Robert Moses State Park on Monday Morning. The small aircraft had three people on board. There were no reported injuries. Photographed on assignment by David Wexler. For more info, click on the link in the bio.

The Winter Jam kicked off at Central Park today, featuring detailed ice sculptures of the Empire State Building and Statue of Liberty, and fun activities for kids in the snow, as photographed by @shawninglima.

LEGO installed a 10-foot, 1,200-pound LEGO brick in Flatiron Plaza to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the "2x4" LEGO, as captured by @marcussantos1. The brick took over 350 hours to construct and was made with over 133,000 individual "2x4's." The gigantic LEGO brick will be on view until Sunday, Jan. 28.
Pedestrians are silhouetted as they cross 42nd Street and 8th Avenue in Midtown earlier today, as captured by @anthony.delmundo.photography.
An overturned crane truck fell next to the Blackrock Automotive Center in Queens today, as photographed by @marcussantos1.

Warda Ibrahim, with two of her nine children, live in a bug infested apartment in NYCHA's Queensbridge Houses. “We can’t live here anymore,” said Ibrahim, whose nine children range in age from 2 months to 19 years old. The family has been overrun with roaches, caused by the backup of fetid water in their tub and sinks – with NYCHA failing to provide adequate help.  Photographed by @susanwatts3, the New York Daily News reached out to NYCHA about the conditions of the apartment. To read the latest on this story,  see the link in our bio.

Today, January 22, 2018, marks the tenth anniversary of Heath Ledger's death. He was 28 years old. Ledger was photographed by NYDN, back in 2004 and 2002. To take a look back at his career in film and television, click on the link in the bio.

The sun rises behind the Statue of Liberty in New York's Harbor as seen from the Liberty State Park in Jersey City early Sunday morning. The Statue of Liberty will reopen on Monday after Gov. Cuomo stated that New York State had reached an agreement to pick up the tab in order to keep Liberty Island open during the government shutdown. For more info, click on the link in the bio. #WomensMarchNYC packed 25 blocks in the Upper West Side today, as marchers including Yoko Ono, Rosie Perez and Mayor Bill de Blasio showed their support for women and their frustration with the Trump presidency one year after his inauguration. Photographed by @shawninglima, @isabelslepoy and @danimacphoto. For more photos from the march, see the link in our bio.

Mourners grieve at a memorial on Tuesday for Shaquana Button, who was fatally shot in front of a deli in the Bronx on Monday night, as photographed by @jameskeivom. Police released a photo of the man wanted in connection with her murder today. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

The New York @mets reintroduce right fielder Jay Bruce with a three-year, $39 million deal at Citi Field earlier today, as photographed by Howard Simmons. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

NYPD Officers Carlos Guadalupe and Tiffany Phillips pose for a photo at Bellevue Hospital as they tell reporters how they delivered a baby inside a car in Manhattan earlier today, as photographed by Andrew Savulich. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

King was photographed by NYDN staffer Frank Hurley during the March on Washington as he waves to a huge crowd at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C. on Wednesday, August 28, 1963. Patricia Ann Norris-McDonald, the widow of NYPD Detective Steven McDonald, points at a plaque honoring her husband at the Central Park Precinct on Wednesday, the one year anniversary of his death. Escher, a 4-year-old Nederlandse Kooikerhondje, basks in the spotlight during an American Kennel Club press conference revealing their newly recognized cat and dog breeds in Manhattan today, as photographed by Jefferson Siegel. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

@georgetownathletics Hoyas head coach Patrick Ewing greets @stjohnsbball head coach Chris Mullin before the start of the Georgetown vs. St. John's basketball game at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday, as photographed by Howard Simmons. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Foster parent Virginie Fields and her new pup St. Vincent, a 10- to- 12-year-old shepherd mix that was found in a garbage bag in Brooklyn, as he is released from an animal hospital on Friday, as photographed by @byronsmithphoto. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Andrea Gibbon hugs her slain daughter's boyfriend at the funeral for Desiree Gibbon, 26, today, as photographed by @debbieeganchin. Desiree was found with her throat slashed in St. James Parish, Jamaica, in November, and was laid to rest in Queens. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Actress Chrissie Fit was photographed by staffer @susanwatts3 , reprises her role as Florencia "Flo" Fuentes in "Pitch Perfect 3" which comes out on Friday. For more on Chrissie's interview, click on the link in the bio.

Peter and Delilah Vega, 12, and their sister Genesis Villella, 20, the children of slain NYPD Officer Miosotis Familia, react as they see their new apartment for the first time in the Bronx earlier today, as captured by @jameskeivom. The iconic Koenig Sphere officially returned to the World Trade Center site in a re-dedication ceremony at Liberty Park in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday morning. Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders, left, joined NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio, 2nd from left, on a trip on the A Train from 34th Street-Penn Station to the Fulton Center station for a campaign rally on Monday. Photographed by staffer @jameskeivom.

It has been over a month since Hurricane Maria hit the island of Puerto Rico, here is an aerial view of the damaged homes in Utuado, Puerto Rico. In the second image, Local residents of Utuado, were collecting water from a water hole with empty plastic bottles. Wide variety of different bottles, such as empty water, soda, juice and oil containers. Photographed by staffer @marcussantos1 captured what it is like in the aftermath of the storm, to see more images, click on the link in the bio.

Have you been to the Levain Bakery? It is located near the B Train station at 81st St.-Museum of Natural History. They are famously soft, and over-sized cookies! For more from our series Subway Fare: Eating along the B line, check out the link in our bio. Photographed by Rachel Wharton.

Five years since Hurricane Sandy, Marcia Sikowitz, mother of Sandy victim Jacob Vogelman, photographed with Jacob's picture. She poses in front of a handmade quilt made out of his favorite t-shirts that hangs in his bedroom in Brooklyn. Jacob, 24, was with his friend Jessie walking her dog Max the night of the hurricane when they were killed by a falling tree. For more info, click on the link in the bio.  Photographed by staffer @debbieeganchin

Happy Birthday Lady Liberty! 131 years ago today, the Statue of Liberty was dedicated to celebrate French-American relations based on friendship and democracy. Photos captured NYDN photographers by Andrew Theodorakis, Michael Appleton and Ron Antonelli.

Jamoneisha Merritt, 11, dances as her mother Ebony and FDNY Commissioner Daniel Nigro look on while swearing in Merritt as an honorary firefighter yesterday, as photographed by NYDN staffer Jefferson Siegel. Activists splattered red paint on the statue of President Theodore Roosevelt outside of the American Museum of Natural History earlier today in Manhattan, as captured by NYDN staff photographer @anthony.delmundo.photography. For more on this story, see the link in our bio.

Eddie Sowell and his 4-year-old son Kiyan visit his brother Jason's mural in Coney Island. Jason Sowell, the 6-foot-4 starting forward for city and state champion Lincoln High School, was shot to death with a friend's gun on Aug. 6, 1995. Five years younger, Eddie was just 11-years-old and vividly remembers that devastating day. He has tattooed Jason's jersey number 11 on his back and "my brother's keeper”. To see more of the R.I.P. murals photographed by NYDN staffer Debbie Egan-Chin, click on the link in the bio.

Lenny Rosado is pictured in front of his daughter Leandra’s mural. Leandra died in October 2009, when she was among seven girls who piled into a 1988 Mercury Sable for a trip to a slumber party. The driver was drunk and hit speeds of 80 mph on the Henry Hudson Parkway. The car flipped three times and smashed into a tree, ejecting three passengers, including Leandra, who was the only one killed. Motivated by his daughter's death, Rosado pushed for passage of Leandra's Law - a state measure that made it a felony to drive drunk with a child in a car. To see more of the R.I.P. murals photographed by NYDN staffer Debbie Egan-Chin, click on the link in the bio.

In a moving ceremony in the shadow of the old St. Vincent’s Hospital — the epicenter of the AIDS crisis in the 1980s — city officials and advocates marked World AIDS Day in the West Village Thursday with promises to continue to fight the deadly disease. Then & Now: Since 1927, the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade has drawn millions of spectators to the streets of New York City, becoming a favorite holiday tradition for kids and adults alike. It wasn't until the parade made its debut in the 1947 film "Miracle on 34th Street" that it became known nationally. Fun fact: Macy's employees are cast in more than half of the roles in the beloved film. Have a fantastic Turkey Day — bonus points if you leave us your favorite dish in the comments! 🦃(George Rinhart/Corbis via Getty Images)

Ralph Branca, who gave up one of the most famous home runs in baseball history, died Wednesday morning. The Mount Vernon product was 90.

Ex-Mets manager Bobby Valentine, who is married to Branca's daughter Mary, shared the news on Twitter: "In his 91st year on Earth he left us with the same dignity and grace that defined his everyday on earth. He will be truly missed!!!" (AP Photo/File)
Today from Bill Bramhall.

It has been 53 years since John F. Kennedy was assassinated on Nov. 22, 1963, an event the shocked the nation. Television viewers watched in horror as the president was shot while travelling in a presidential motorcade in Dallas with his wife, Jackie, and Texas governor John Connally, who survived. The tragic assassination defined a generation, and forever altered the way breaking news was reported. Here, John F. Kennedy laughs during a CBS television interview called "After Two Years: A Conversation with the President" on Dec. 16, 1962. (Getty Images).

The daughter of Olympic sprinter Tyson Gay was following in her father’s fast footsteps before she was struck down and killed by a stray bullet early Sunday outside a Kentucky eatery.

Fifteen-year-old Trinity Gay, herself a rising track star, was innocently hanging out with friends when she was randomly shot in the neck outside a barbecue spot in Lexington, police said. “I should never have to bury my child,” the teen's mother Shoshana Boyd, told the Daily News. “She wanted to be the fastest woman in the world, and they took that away from her.” Read the full story via the link in our profile.

Jia Jia, the world’s oldest-ever panda in captivity, was euthanized today at 38 due to deteriorating health. The average lifespan for a panda in the wild is 18 to 20 years, while in captivity it’s 30 years, according to Guinness World Records. (Philippe Lopez/AFP/Getty Images)

📽Today in 1955, American actor James Dean died in Southern California. Dean was driving his Porsche 550 Spyder, nicknamed "Little Bastard," when he was involved in a car crash. He was only 24 years old. At the time of his death, only one of his movies — "East of Eden" — had been released. He was on his way up as a rising star, but when "Rebel Without a Cause" and "Giant" opened shortly after his early demise, he was launched into the legendary lane. Follow the link in the bio to take a look at the life and career of one of Hollywood's greatest stars 💫(Hulton Archive/Getty Images)
Today's Bill Bramhall cartoon.

Ramarley Graham's mother, Constance Malcolm, and father, Franclot Graham, want answers. They filed a sweeping Freedom of Information request today because they say a slew of information about the death of their 18-year-old son has been concealed since he was shot by police more than four and a half years ago. “How would de Blasio feel, or Chirlane McCray feel if this was Dante? How would they feel?" Constance asked. "They would want the same answers.” (Howard Simmons/New York Daily News)

Every year on September 11, the Tribute in Light commemorates the victims of the terrorist attacks on the twin towers of the World Trade Center in 2001. One unanticipated consequence of the memorial — which consists of 88 7,000-watt bulbs that form two beams of light, visible from miles away — is the adverse effect they have on migrating birds that pass over Lower Manhattan at this time.

Watch the latest Daily Dig (link in bio 👆) to see how volunteers are making sure migrating flocks get to their destination safely.

Here's a look inside the car window of the father of accused terrorist bomber Ahmad Khan Rahami. Mohammad Rahami says he contacted the FBI in 2014 when his son turned violent after a trip to Afghanistan, saying: “My son, he’s doing really bad, OK?” After a two-month probe, the FBI told Mohammad that Ahmad was “clear — he’s not a terrorist," Mohammad said. "Now, (they) say he’s a terrorist. I say OK.” Mohammad says that the FBI's failures made way for the bombing. Learn more about the climate inside the Rahami home, as well as the trips to Pakistan and Afghanistan that “radicalized” Ahmad Rahami by following the link in the bio. (Corey Sipkin/New York Daily News)

JUSTICE -- The Bronx cabbie charged with assault for fatally beating a would-be-rapist who attacked his wife walked out of court a free man this afternoon.

Mamadou Diallo was all smiles as he left the building and pushed through a throng of reporters. “I’m happy for the American justice, and it’s the best way in the world, that’s what I say,” he told the press. 
Read how the Bronx DA came to this decision via the link in our bio. (Benjamin Kochman/ New York Daily News)

Hermine is still hanging on, even though the storm's force is slowly weakening as it churns along the northeastern shore. Swimmers were urged to stay out of the water today as powerful and potentially deadly rip tides formed off northeastern beaches, and tropical storm warnings remained in effect today from Long Island all the way up to Massachusetts. New York's beaches are expected to reopen for business tomorrow and stay open until Sept. 12. (Debbie Egan-Chin/New York Daily News)

Mother Teresa, after a lifetime amid the world’s indigent, unwanted, sick and dying, will spend eternity among the saints.

The beloved nun, with her wrinkled face and wide grin, completes her journey from Calcutta’s filthiest slums to the highest echelon of the Catholic Church with her Sunday canonization.

Her elevation comes one day before the 19th anniversary of her death. And it comes as no surprise to those who say “The Saint of the Gutters” deserved the honor while she was still alive. Follow the link in our bio to read more. (GERALD HERBERT/NEW YORK DAILY NEWS)

You may recognize Brooklyn rapper @joeybadass on the TV screen in “Mr. Robot,” on a giant Calvin Klein billboard in SoHo, or on the radio with his catchy single “Devastated.” To many, it seems the 21-year-old is having his breakout year.

But in hip hop circles, the rapper, whose real name is Jo-Vaughn Virginie Scott, has been well-known since he dropped his first mixtape “1999” four years ago. Fans who weren’t accustomed to hearing his work on the radio or seeing his face on TV cried “sell out!” But that doesn’t bother him. "Well, you know, we did sell out...every ticket on the ScHoolboy Q tour." Follow the link in the bio to read more about what Joey Bada$$ has to say about independent music, struggle, family, and of course: Brooklyn. (@twlevinson/New York Daily News) #JoeyBadass #Brooklyn

If you were planning on hitting the beach this Labor Day Weekend, you need to make a change of plans. "Extremely dangerous" rip tides that haven't been seen in 15 years are possible this weekend — all thanks to Hurricane Hermine, currently battering Florida's gulf coast. For now, city beaches will be closed for swimming on Sunday and possibly Labor Day, the mayor said. And regardless of your plans, nasty weather is expected to kick off early Sunday and extend through the following Wednesday. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Late summer, 1945. In the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, more than 100,000 people lay dead, casualties of the United States’ decision to drop a pair of atomic bombs. But in Times Square on Aug. 14, a much different vibe prevails: Japan has surrendered, and the victors are celebrating — drinking, shouting and dancing in the streets.

An American sailor named George Mendonsa spontaneously takes hold of a complete stranger, 21-year-old Austrian-Jewish refugee Greta Zimmer, bends her backward, plants a kiss on her mouth and continues on his way. Unbeknown to either, famed photojournalist Alfred Eisenstaedt has captured the encounter. 
The celebrated image has taken on a sinister shade in 2016, with many saying it's nothing short of sexual assault. Read the full story via the link in our bio. (Alfred Eisenstadt/Time Life Pictures/Getty Images)

She asked for understanding, but all she got was crickets — and handcuffs. Zaida Pugh, 21, was arrested for tossing crickets on a crowded D train during rush hour last week, and urinating on herself as part of a bizarre stunt. The antics sparked panic that led one rider to pull the emergency brake, and the train stalled on the Manhattan Bridge for an agonizing half-hour. Though she said the purpose of her stunt was to bring awareness to the way homeless people are treated in the city, it doesn't seem like anyone had a grasp on the message of Pugh's performance. (Todd Maisel/New York Daily News)

Lamiya Aji Bashar is an 18-year-old Yazidi girl who escaped her ISIS enslavers. She is one of roughly 3,000 women and girls who are sold on ISIS' sex slave market using Telegram and WhatsApp – a use of technology that makes it extremely difficult to escape through checkpoints. Lamiya tried to flee four times before finally escaping in March with two companions: 8-year-old Almas and 20-year-old Katherine. As they fled, a land mine exploded. The blast killed her companions and left her blind in her right eye, her face scarred by melted skin. But she insists: "Even if I had lost both eyes, it would have been worth it, because I have survived them." (Balint Szlanko/Associated Press)

Mugging victim Maria Lugo’s apartment smells a little less like fear.
The 80-year-old woman, who lost her television, $300 cash and her favorite perfume during a June 23 armed robbery, cried Saturday after a Daily News reader sent her a brand new bottle of Chanel Chance.
“Thank you to the people that gave me this gift,” said the appreciative Brooklyn grandmom. “Thank you so much. This means that there are good people on the streets that have hearts big enough to feel bad about an old lady like me.”
Lugo said she was still horribly shaken by the Sumner House robbery where three men pushed their way into her apartment at gunpoint.
The senior citizen was shoved face-down to the floor of her sixth-floor kitchen as the terrifying trio ransacked the Bedford-Stuyvesant home that she shares with her daughter and grandson.
Donor Kim Waters, 35, of the Upper West Side, said the sight of the diminutive Lugo’s picture in The News brought back memories of her late 103-year-old aunt. 
In a letter to Lugo, Waters wrote: “Ms. Lugo, we may never meet but know we are connected by our mutual love for perfume. This bottle may not erase the horrible ordeal you experienced, nor will it replace your favorite perfume, yet I hope and pray it will bring more beauty, happiness, and pleasure to your days.” (Kevin C. Downs for New York Daily News)

A look at our front page.... 97 years ago. This was the first Daily News cover on our debut, June 26, 1919. For 97 years, The Daily News did its best to keep that promise as it celebrated heroes, chronicled countless heartbreaks, triumphs and tragedies, stood up to mayors and shamed Presidents, earning a passel of Pulitzers and other prizes in the process.

Horses enter the track in the early morning — racehorse workouts start as early as 5:30 a.m., once the track opens. Photographs like this one, shot from a low angle, are not always easy to get. Racehorses get spooked if a person is kneeling low near them. One either needs to keep some distance or stay standing and hold the camera low. (Corey Sipkin/ New York Daily News) #belmont #belmontstakes

Dave Cannizzo rides one of the racehorses as seen through the missing piece of a fence on the main track. Cannizzo comes from a racing family and got involved at a young age by putting on bandages. In 2015, Cannizzo was suspended for 30 days and fined $6G for doping three horses. (Corey Sipkin/ New York Daily News) #belmont #belmontstakes

Belmont Stakes longshot Governor Malibu cruises down the racetrack with an exercise rider in the irons. Governor Malibu has the inside post in the field of 13 3-year-olds aiming to win the $800,000 grand prize. (Corey Sipkin/ New York Daily News) #belmont #belmontstakes

A horse strides down the track wearing orange wrappings on its rear legs during an early morning workout on the main track. Wrappings provide support and can protect from injury, but not all horses use them. The type of wraps a horse uses may depend on the type of work they do that day. Different workout examples include breezing, galloping and jogging. Applying the wraps takes skill, as pressure needs to be applied evenly. (Corey Sipkin/ New York Daily News) #belmont #belmontstakes

The shadow of a racehorse and his hot walker stretches outside Barn 30 near the racecourse in Elmont, NY. The horse prepares for a bath after training on the track. A hot walker's job is to hand-walk hot, sweaty horses after a workout on the racetrack. (Corey Sipkin/ New York Daily News) #belmont #belmontstakes

With the 148th annual Belmont Stakes kicking off today at 3 p.m., Daily News photographer Corey Sipkin gives us a behind-the-scenes look at training in the days before the race.

Pictured is an early morning view on the main track, with the grandstand sitting in the distant background. Nicknamed "Big Sandy," the 1.5-mile main track at Belmont Park is the longest dirt racecourse in North American thoroughbred racing. (Corey Sipkin/ New York Daily News) #belmont #belmontstakes

Duke was A-No. 1.

The dog, a veteran NYPD canine named for a famed villain from the movie “Escape from New York,” was put to rest Wednesday. “It was very hard. I couldn’t ask for a better partner,” said Detective William Hernandez, 46, of Long Island.

The 13-year-old crime-fighting German shepherd suffered from hip dysplasia and couldn’t stand on his hind legs anymore, Hernandez said.

The detective got paired with Duke in 2004, and named him after Isaac Hayes’ imposing character from the 1981 John Carpenter film.

Duke made six arrests — including a suspect in a Staten Island pharmacy burglary — and two crooks surrendered when they heard the pooch was on his way to get them, he said.

Duke, who retired in 2012, also won first place in a 2009 United States Police Canine Association competition, Hernandez said. “I was so confident with him going to jobs,” Hernandez said. “He had my back.” (Todd Maisel / New York Daily News)

Sister Gertrude Inenacho, the congregation minister at the Motherhouse of the Franciscan Handmaids of the Most Pure Heart of Mary, on Wednesday, March 23, 2016 in New York, N.Y.  This Harlem-based order, one of only three orders of black nuns in the United States, was on the  brink of closure in 2014, but a message from Pope Francis kept the order alive – and the nuns are preparing to celebrate their 100th anniversary Tuesday, March 29,  with a star-studded event. (@jameskeivom / New York Daily News)

Six firefighters were hospitalized after a raging fire ripped through a vacant century-old Brooklyn home Wednesday, officials said.
The fire was sparked into the Stratford Road address near Dorchester Road in Ditmas Park about 12:45 p.m. More than 100 firefighters were called in to put out the blistering blaze, which was put out about 2:30 p.m. Neighbors said that the home was over 100 years old and had been vacant for some time. (Todd Maisel/ New York Daily News)

“We’re as mad as hell, and we’re not going to take this anymore!” @reservedmagazine Issue No. 3 held a launch party tonight in Tribeca, featuring performance artists, seen here, at a pop-up gallery by filmmaker Jennifer Elster. The magazine itself was created in 2013 in response to ‘low quality’ content populating the ether, and aims to cause a stir in the arts and culture industry with visual arts, film, fashion, photography, music — they don’t have a formula. But there is one hard and fast rule for the mag and its creators: their kryptonite is boredom. Whatever it is they decide to experiment with, they say, it better be interesting. (📷 @dianacreports/Daily News)

“We are very concerned. I believe that something else is happening. I don’t think Richard is in there of his own volition.” Richard Simmons has vanished from public view, and many who know him best say they haven’t had contact with him in more than two years. He’s stopped returning calls and emails, and his housekeeper maintains that he merely wants to be alone. But his closest friends believe something more sinister is at work. Follow the link in the bio for more of the story.
This morning from Bill Bramhall. Which train do you spend the most time waiting on?

David Christgau's grandfather and uncle are both retired chiefs, and two more uncles are on the job, one as a battalion chief and the other as a lieutenant. He has taken the Fire Department test and is currently on the list to enter the academy. (@susanwatts3/ New York Daily News)

Across the country, more than 2 million people make their living in the food service industry, working as waiters, hostesses, bartenders. In New York City, it’s a small army that numbers in the tens of thousands. But while today they may dutifully bring you your steak or serve up your Manhattan, many of them are also working just as hard toward tomorrow. They aren’t waiting for anything. In this stunning series of images, Daily News photographer Susan Watts shows you what your waiter or waitress might look like through a different lens — after they’ve chased down their dreams.

Even if she #KnowsHerStatus, about one in four women postpones medical care because of barriers such as family, depression, or threat of partner violence, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services reports. No matter what your age, ethnicity or sexual orientation, no one is immune from the transmission of HIV, and the only way you can know for sure whether or not you have HIV is to get tested. Find out if you're eligible to receive the test, and counseling, at no cost to you by visiting womenshealth.gov online.

Five Coast Guard officers on a rescue mission ended up becoming the ones in distress early Thursday when their vessel capsized off the Rockaways during a massive storm, officials said.

The 25-foot Response Boat Small was buffeted by 10- to 12-foot waves before flipping over in the East Rockaway Inlet about 5 a.m.

The seamen were treated at the scene. No injuries were reported. (Debbie Egan-Chin/ New York Daily News)

Just days ahead of the Academy Awards, several actors, directors and producers revealed their experiences with racism and sexism in Hollywood to the New York Times: "I genuinely didn't realize that she was asking me to speak English with a broken accent," actress @americaferrera told the Times. "It confused me, because I thought, I am Latino, so isn't this what a Latino sounds like? From the get-go of my career I thought there's a certain box or a certain way that you're seen, which I didn't feel growing up."

Last night's powerful storm socked the city, seriously injuring one man in the Bronx after more than a dozen bricks were blown off of a Highbridge building. Here, the wind and rain assisted in collapsing this vacant building at 183 St. and Cambreleng Ave. in the Bronx. Photo by our own Vic Nicastro.
Kyle Haynes, of the New York Yankees, tosses a ball across a rain-covered George M. Steinbrenner Field in Tampa, Florida, Feb. 24,  2016. #Yankees #SpringTraining (Corey Sipkin/New York Daily News)

NYPD Police Officer William Reddin was released from Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn on Tuesday, Feb. 23, 2016. Officer Reddin had been shot in the hip early Friday after a gunfight with a man in Bedford Stuyvesant. He is accompanied by his wife, Vanessa, and his two children, Devon and Nathan. "He's my hero," said Assistant Chief Jeffrey Maddrey, the commanding officer of Patrol Borough Brooklyn North, who joined in the celebration. "He (knew) Saturday morning when he was going up against that armed gunman that he had the support of the NYPD and as he walked out here today he saw and he knew that he had the support of the NYPD." (Todd Maisel/ New York Daily News)

This Brooklyn teen went from hearing violence to violins. Growing up in Bedford-Stuyvesant, he heard gunshots every night, he said. But he found peace in another sound: playing the violin. He won a $2,000 John Juzek violin through an essay contest, where he talked about the importance of music in his life. Check NYDN.us for the full story. Photo by our own Susan Watts.

A restaurant in Buffalo is offering a 10% discount to those who can stay off their phones for an entire meal. Customers who are up for the challenge are tasked with putting their phones in a bread basket until the bill comes. "Why do you even go out to dinner? It's a chance to have a one-on-one conversation with somebody," the owner says. "Now it's so hard to even do that." Would you be willing to keep off your phone in favor of the discount? 📵 See the link in our profile for more on the story. (Photo: Jason Silverstein/New York Daily News)

Today's NYC history lesson: For more than six decades, this retro Pepsi-Cola sign sat atop a company bottling plant in Queens before eventually moving to its perch in Long Island City's Gantry Plaza State Park. Bonus: Its neon lights still illuminate the East River at night! 👌 Nostalgic #NYDNgram by @pictures_of_newyork.

Joining Eighth Avenue, Central Park West, Central Park South and Broadway, Columbus Circle has held down Central Park's southwest corner since 1905. Named after Christopher Columbus, the marble statue at the center was erected in 1892 to celebrate the 400th anniversary of his arrival to the Americas. #NYDNgram by @allisonjkruse

Tourists on the High Line can't help but capture the beauty of New York City.

On top, you're looking at Castle Williams on Governors Island. Below it is a miniature replica of the early 19th century fort. Named after its designer, Jonathan Williams, it was built between 1807-1811 to fortify New York City's naval defenses in case of a war with Europe. By the time the War of 1812 erupted, the then state-of-the-art fort was ready to defend New York harbor. #NYC #NewYork #CastleWilliams
